sections.title: Overview
sections.md: The smallest and innermost planet, Mercury endures scorching days and freezing nights with virtually no atmosphere to trap heat.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: NASA's MESSENGER orbited Mercury from 2011 to 2015, revealing a cratered surface and clues about its magnetic field; ESA's BepiColombo will arrive in 2025.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: A runaway-greenhouse world shrouded in sulfuric acid clouds. Surface pressures crush and temperatures melt lead, yet the geology hints at active processes.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: Magellan mapped the surface by radar; upcoming missions like DAVINCI and VERITAS aim to probe atmosphere, composition, and tectonics.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: Our home planet, rich with oceans, atmosphere, and life. Earth's magnetic field and moderate climate make it unique among known worlds.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: From Apollo to Artemis, human and robotic missions continue to study our planet from orbit and beyond, monitoring its climate and ecosystems.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: The Red Planet preserves ancient river valleys and polar ice caps. Today it's cold and dry, but its rocks record a wetter, potentially habitable past.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: Perseverance and Curiosity explore habitability and collect samples; orbiters like MAVEN study atmosphere loss and climate history.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: The largest planet in the Solar System, Jupiter is a gas giant with swirling storms and over 90 moons, including Europa, Ganymede, and Io.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: NASA's Juno continues to study Jupiter’s atmosphere and magnetosphere; ESA’s JUICE mission will explore its icy moons.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: A majestic gas giant adorned with spectacular rings made of ice and rock, Saturn is a world of deep winds and dozens of moons.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: Cassini’s 13-year mission revealed Saturn’s intricate ring structure and the potential habitability of its moon Enceladus.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: An ice giant tipped on its side, Uranus experiences extreme seasons and a pale blue hue from methane in its atmosphere.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: Voyager 2’s 1986 flyby remains our only close encounter; future missions aim to study its rings and atmospheric dynamics.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: A deep-blue ice giant with supersonic winds and evolving storms at the fringes of the solar system.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: Voyager 2 (1989) remains our only flyby; modern telescopes continue to track weather and seasonal changes.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: A distant dwarf planet with complex geology and a famous heart-shaped plain, Tombaugh Regio, sculpted by nitrogen and carbon monoxide ices.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: New Horizons (2015) transformed Pluto from a point of light into a dynamic world with mountains, glaciers, and a surprisingly active surface.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: Earth’s only natural satellite, the Moon has shaped our tides, calendars, and culture for millennia. Its surface is scarred by craters and basins from ancient impacts.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: From the Apollo landings to modern Artemis missions, the Moon remains a key focus for exploration and future habitation.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: An icy moon likely hiding a global subsurface ocean beneath a fractured crust—one of the most promising places to search for life beyond Earth.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: Galileo revealed a young, active surface; NASA's Europa Clipper is en route to probe the ocean, chemistry, and potential habitability.

sections.title: Overview
sections.md: A world with a thick nitrogen atmosphere, methane clouds, and lakes—Earth-like weather cycles with alien chemistry at cryogenic temperatures.

sections.title: Missions
sections.md: Cassini–Huygens dropped a lander into Titan’s haze; NASA’s Dragonfly rotorcraft will hop between sites to study prebiotic chemistry.
